User:1c3fe5ef9e81.name: Nikit Bhandari
User:1c3fe5ef9e81.bio: Android developer @GojekTech -> Find more about me here https://nikit19.github.io/

Paragraph:69580c23891f_1.name: efbf
Paragraph:69580c23891f_1.text: Photo by Michael Pfister on Unsplash

Paragraph:69580c23891f_2.name: b30c
Paragraph:69580c23891f_2.text: In this blog post we will learn how to make a Toolbar and a Bottom Navigation Bar in Jetpack Compose.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_3.name: 05d7
Paragraph:69580c23891f_3.text: If you are interested in exploring other components in Jetpack Compose you can check out the series of articles that I have written.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_5.text: How to make a Scrollable list in Jetpack Compose?

Paragraph:69580c23891f_7.text: Creating AppBars in Jetpack Compose (You are here)

Paragraph:69580c23891f_8.name: f58e
Paragraph:69580c23891f_8.text: How to use Tabs in Jetpack Compose?

Paragraph:69580c23891f_11.name: 1ba6
Paragraph:69580c23891f_11.text: Animations in Jetpack Compose using Transition

Paragraph:69580c23891f_12.name: d858
Paragraph:69580c23891f_12.text: There are two types of AppBars in Jetpack Compose: TopAppBar and BottomAppBar. Let’s explore TopAppBar first.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_13.name: 558c
Paragraph:69580c23891f_13.text: TopAppBar in Jetpack Compose is basically the toolbar in Android. There are two implementations of TopAppBar in Jetpack Compose, let’s explore their method signatures one by one.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_15.name: 67ed
Paragraph:69580c23891f_15.text: This is pretty straight forward. In the title, you can specify the text that appears on the toolbar. You can use color to specify the color of the toolbar by default it uses the primary color of the theme that you are using. navigationIcon is an icon that appears on the left side of the title, typically used to open the navigation drawer, although you can customise what happens on clicking on the navigationIcon in your implementation.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_16.text: Let’s have a look at the second implementation of TopAppBar.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_18.name: 08f5
Paragraph:69580c23891f_18.text: Two additional fields that we see here are actionData and action. Although the naming is a bit weird but all they do is tell you what actionData should be shown at the end of the toolbar. You can have at max 2 icons in the toolbar other than the navigationIcon, if you use more than 2 icons then the extra icons should appear in an overflow menu but as you can see in the comment above, this functionality is still not there. action defines what should be done when the user clicks on your actionData in the toolbar. For instance if your actionData is a search icon, the action would be to allow you to search for something. The following example will make things more clear.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_20.name: abaf
Paragraph:69580c23891f_20.text: Here we have set the title of the toolbar using a Text component. We are providing an image of the search icon in the actionData. AppBarIcon is used to make an icon in the toolbar using the image which we provide in the actionData. AppBarIcon is also used to make the navigationIcon. The screenshot below shows the result of the above code.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_22.name: 11ec
Paragraph:69580c23891f_22.text: Let’s explore the other AppBar which is BottomAppBar. BottomAppBar is basically the Bottom Navigation bar in Android. Let’s have a look at its method signature.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_24.text: You might notice that BottomAppBar has a similar method signature as TopAppBar, fabConfiguration is the only field that is different. If you don’t need a fab just let the field be null otherwise you can configure the fab according to your needs. FabConfiguration is a data class which looks like this

Paragraph:69580c23891f_26.name: c60e
Paragraph:69580c23891f_26.text: Basically here you can specify the position of the fab which takes a default value of centre, other than that you can place it at the right side. cutoutShape is the shape that will be cut off from the BottomAppBar to fit the fab. The following example will make things more clear.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_28.name: b7cb
Paragraph:69580c23891f_28.text: The code snippet above is similar to how we setup the TopAppBar. Only difference is here we have to define the fabConfiguration as well. We are using circleShape in cutOutShape, the gap between the BottomAppBar and fab that you see in the screenshot below is because of this parameter, you can pass a null value if you don’t want it. navigationIcon is the left most icon in the BottomAppBar just like it was in TopAppBar.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_30.text: When you have a fab which is centred then you can have at max 2 icons in the BottomAppBar in addition to the navigationIcon otherwise if there is no fab or the fab is positioned in the end you can have at max 4 icons in the BottomAppBar.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_31.name: 65af
Paragraph:69580c23891f_31.text: This is how you can use AppBars in Jetpack Compose to create TopAppBar and BottomAppBar.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_32.name: 427b
Paragraph:69580c23891f_32.text: One thing that I realised after exploring AppBars is that I never thought Bottom Navigation Bar and Toolbar worked in a similar manner and lot of code can be reused like it has been done in Jetpack Compose. Jetpack Compose is really promising and I can’t wait to see its stable version!

Paragraph:69580c23891f_33.name: 48e8
Paragraph:69580c23891f_33.text: The code snippets used in this blog post are from this repository, feel free to check it out.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_35.name: f9a5
Paragraph:69580c23891f_35.text: Jetpack Compose is still in developer preview, there will be breaking changes in the future so some of the things that I mentioned might change over time.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_36.name: 3c07
Paragraph:69580c23891f_36.text: Thanks for reading! If you enjoyed this story, please click the 👏 button and share it to help others!

Paragraph:69580c23891f_37.name: 0aac
Paragraph:69580c23891f_37.text: If you have any kind of feedback, feel free to connect with me on Twitter.

Paragraph:69580c23891f_38.name: 100b
Paragraph:69580c23891f_38.text:
Nikit Bhandari
The latest Tweets from Nikit Bhandari (@NikitBhandari). Android developer | Open source enthusiast | Dreamer. Delhitwitter.com
